TextEquiv.Unicode: ordered, we ought all of us to use great
diligence, that in this behalf there may
no offence bee committed through our
carelesnesse and negligence.
This much have I saide concer
ning Ecclesiasticall schooles, in as few
woordes as might conveniently: of
which I have intreated more at large
in my booke of the institution of By
shops.
Furthermore, to the end that schooles
with ye whole ministery may be main,
tained, togither with al holy buildings
and Ecclesiasticall chareges, there nee
deth to be some good wealth and abili
tie correspondent.
This place therfore ad monisheth us
to say somewhat concerning Ecclesi
asticall goods. God in that common
welth which he would have to ercell al
other as best furnished with all things
necessarie, appointed standing fees to
be paid unto the holy ministerie of the
common charege, to wit, the tithes, the
first fruites, and sundrie other kinds of
offeringes.
These thinges are in the lawe ex
pressed by Moses the man of God in
many wordes: who nothing feared,
least for handling of that matter hee
should be accused of greedie desire, or
covetousnesse. For those thinges
which God commaunded him to de
clare plainely to the people, hee utte
red unto them faithfully. Pea, the
lawe of nature commaundeth to re
warde him that taketh paine, and to
maintaine common chareges by com
mon contribution. And those reve
nues or tributes that were publique
lie gathered, were not bestowed but
to publique uses. For they were partly
give to the ministers for their ministe
ry & seruice, partly they were disbursed
upon publique buildinges & holy char
ges, and part was imployed to the re

ordered, we ought all of us to use great diligence, that in this behalf there may no offence bee committed through our carelesnesse and negligence. This much have I saide concer ning Ecclesiasticall schooles, in as few woordes as might conveniently: of which I have intreated more at large in my booke of the institution of By shops. Furthermore, to the end that schooles with ye whole ministery may be main, tained, togither with al holy buildings and Ecclesiasticall chareges, there nee deth to be some good wealth and abili tie correspondent. This place therfore ad monisheth us to say somewhat concerning Ecclesi asticall goods. God in that common welth which he would have to ercell al other as best furnished with all things necessarie, appointed standing fees to be paid unto the holy ministerie of the common charege, to wit, the tithes, the first fruites, and sundrie other kinds of offeringes. These thinges are in the lawe ex pressed by Moses the man of God in many wordes: who nothing feared, least for handling of that matter hee should be accused of greedie desire, or covetousnesse. For those thinges which God commaunded him to de clare plainely to the people, hee utte red unto them faithfully. Pea, the lawe of nature commaundeth to re warde him that taketh paine, and to maintaine common chareges by com mon contribution. And those reve nues or tributes that were publique lie gathered, were not bestowed but to publique uses. For they were partly give to the ministers for their ministe ry & seruice, partly they were disbursed upon publique buildinges & holy char ges, and part was imployed to the re
liefe of the poore.
And although by the newe Testa
ment the Levitical law with ye whole
Priesthood be abrogated, notwithstan
ding it is certaine that ye same univer
sall law, which commandeth that pub
lique chareges should bee levied by pub
lique contributions, is not abolished.
For we read that our Lorde Jesus
Christe, although hee lived not of the
tenths & revenves of the Priestes, yet
lived he of the cotributions of the god
ly. For hee executed a publique functi
on. And sending his disciples abroade
to preach, expressely saith unto themg
would not have you to be carefull for
foode and apparell: for the labourer is
worthie of his hire.
Therefore the primitive Church
which the Apostles have gathered to
Christ, bestowed their houses, landes
and money for the preseruation of the
ministerie, and other things necessarie
for the Church,
The Priestes and Levites at that
time possessed the holy revenves, not
giving one iote to the Apostolique
Church, which rather they wished
might sterve for hunger. But the godly
and faithfull people knewe very well,
that earthly substance and riches were
very necessarie for the preseruation of
the Church,
For God hath appointed men & not
Angels to be ministers of the Church:
and hath recommended poore men un
to the Church to stande in his stead.
But they as men are wout to doe,
lacke & are destitute of many thinges,
wherefore good men through the moti
on of the holy Ghost, doe contribute to
gether, & bestow money, houses, lands,
and other goods, wherby both the poore
and also the holy ministerie may bee
maintained.
And hereupon also it is evident that

liefe of the poore. And although by the newe Testa ment the Levitical law with ye whole Priesthood be abrogated, notwithstan ding it is certaine that ye same univer sall law, which commandeth that pub lique chareges should bee levied by pub lique contributions, is not abolished. For we read that our Lorde Jesus Christe, although hee lived not of the tenths & revenves of the Priestes, yet lived he of the cotributions of the god ly. For hee executed a publique functi on. And sending his disciples abroade to preach, expressely saith unto themg would not have you to be carefull for foode and apparell: for the labourer is worthie of his hire. Therefore the primitive Church which the Apostles have gathered to Christ, bestowed their houses, landes and money for the preseruation of the ministerie, and other things necessarie for the Church, The Priestes and Levites at that time possessed the holy revenves, not giving one iote to the Apostolique Church, which rather they wished might sterve for hunger. But the godly and faithfull people knewe very well, that earthly substance and riches were very necessarie for the preseruation of the Church, For God hath appointed men & not Angels to be ministers of the Church: and hath recommended poore men un to the Church to stande in his stead. But they as men are wout to doe, lacke & are destitute of many thinges, wherefore good men through the moti on of the holy Ghost, doe contribute to gether, & bestow money, houses, lands, and other goods, wherby both the poore and also the holy ministerie may bee maintained.
